newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finland sees cheaper state borrowing in EMU.
newsitem.headline: Finland sees cheaper state borrowing in EMU.

text.p: Finnish state borrowing will be cheaper if Finland joins Europe's planned Economic and Monetary Union than if it stays outside the single currency block, a top finance ministry official said in a statement received Tuesday.
"The third phase of EMU would reduce state borrowing costs from the start of 1999," Kari Nars, the ministry's director of financing, said.

Finnish long-term interest rates had fallen by more than three percentage points in 1995-96 partly thanks to Finland's commitment to EMU, he said. Interest rates "will remain lower inside EMU than outside", he said.
As a member of EMU borrowing in the Euro currency, the Finnish government was likely to have the highest possible credit rating, Nars said.
"The interest of foreigners to buy (Finnish government paper) would no longer be restricted by the markka's exchange rate risk now shunned by many," he said.
Currently, the state's foreign currency borrowing credit ratings are AA minus by Standard & Poor's, Aa2 by Moody's and AA by IBCA.
